The only plausible threat is a Farm Bill with a preemption rider passing before then, but the House remains divided, Republicans are split, and the government is shut down. The overwhelming weight of evidence (legal, legislative, and industry) strongly supports continued enforcement through the resolution date. I estimate the probability that Proposition 12 will be in effect on January 1, 2026, at 92%.

question_details.title: Will California’s 2018 Proposition 12, "Prevention of Cruelty to Farm Animals Act", be in effect on January 1, 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-12-20 21:01:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/31110). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

[Proposition 12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_California_Proposition_12) is a California ballot proposition that expanded upon California's already existing ban on caged farming systems (egg-laying hens kept in battery cages and pregnant sows kept in gestation crates). Under Proposition 12, not only would production of animal products made under intensive caged farming systems be illegal in the state, but so would the sale of such products (regardless of where they were made).

In [*National Pork Producers Council v. Ross*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Pork_Producers_Council_v._Ross), a group of farmers and corporations in the pork industry, led by the [National Pork Producers Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Pork_Producers_Council "National Pork Producers Council") and the [American Farm Bureau Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Farm_Bureau_Federation "American Farm Bureau Federation"), sued the California Department of Food and Agriculture, led by [Karen Ross](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karen_Ross "Karen Ross"). They asserted that the proposition violates the [Dormant Commerce Clause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dormant_Commerce_Clause "Dormant Commerce Clause"), which prohibits laws that impact interstate commerce. The Biden administration [asked the court](https://www.cbsnews.com/sacramento/news/supreme-court-rejects-challenge-to-california-pork-law-mandating-more-space-for-pigs/) to overturn the law in order to protect the country's pork industry, but the Supreme Court rejected the Dormant Commerce Clause argument and [upheld](https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/22pdf/21-468_5if6.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com) Proposition 12.

As of 2024, House Republicans [are attempting](https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/353393/farm-bill-republicans-prop-12-gestation-crates-pork) to overturn Proposition 12, via the the latest [United States farm bill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_farm_bill).

***

This question belongs to Vox's Future Perfect Community page and 2025 forecasting tournament. [Learn more and compete for the $2,500 prize pool](https://www.metaculus.com/c/future-perfect/).

question_details.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if California’s 2018 Proposition 12, "Prevention of Cruelty to Farm Animals Act", is in effect on January 1, 2026. This question will resolve as **No** if it is not in effect for any reason, including but not limited to being overturned by a federal bill, being suspended by a court, or repealed by the California legislature.
question_details.fine_print:
If any portion of Proposition 12 is not in effect then the question will as **No**. The official ballot summary of Proposition 12 is:

> * Establishes new minimum space requirements for confining veal calves, breeding pigs, and egg-laying hens.
> * Requires egg-laying hens be raised in cage-free environment after December 31, 2021.
> * Prohibits certain commercial sales of specified meat and egg products derived from animals confined in noncomplying manner.
> * Defines sales violations as unfair competition.
> * Creates good faith defense for sellers relying upon written certification by suppliers that meat and egg products comply with new confinement standards.
> * Requires State of California to issue implementing regulations.

(Source: Page 68 of the [California Official Voter Information Guide](https://vig.cdn.sos.ca.gov/2018/general/pdf/complete-vig.pdf) for 2018)

The US House of Representative's Farm, Food, and National Security Act of 2024 (also known as the Farm Bill) is an example of legislation that, if it were enacted, would count. In section 12007 (viewable [here](https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/8467/text)), it says:

> \[N]o State or subdivision thereof may enact or enforce, directly or indirectly, as a condition for sale or consumption, any condition or standard of production on products derived from covered livestock not physically raised in such State or subdivision that is in addition to, or different from, the conditions or standards of production in the State in which the production occurs.

In its definition of "covered livestock," the House Farm Bill specifies that covered livestock includes any domestic animal raised for the purpose of slaughter for human consumption, but it specifically does not include domestic animals raised for egg production. If this were enacted this would count for purposes of this question, since it nullifies California's ability to enforce Proposition 12's space requirements for pigs and veal calves, even though it still allows California to enforce Prop 12's space requirements for egg-laying hens.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Farmers are defending the law big pork wants to destroy**
Joe Maxwell, a fourth-generation Missouri hog farmer and president of Farm Action Fund, defends California's Proposition 12, which establishes minimum space standards for animals sold in California, arguing it is not a threat to independent family farmers but rather a market opportunity. He contrasts the interests of large corporate pork producers, represented by the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC), with those of small-scale farmers who benefit from higher welfare standards. Maxwell refutes claims that Proposition 12 caused a 41% rise in pork prices, noting that the significant increase occurred years before the law took effect during pandemic-related market corrections. He asserts that retail pork chop prices in California rose only 6.6% since enforcement began in January 2024, a normal market adjustment. Maxwell emphasizes that the law upholds state authority under federalism, affirmed by the Supreme Court, and warns that proposed federal bills like the Food Security and Farm Protection Act and the Save Our Bacon Act would strip states of this right, favoring corporate control. He argues that the real issue is corporate consolidation, weak antitrust enforcement, and vertical integration by multinational packers like Smithfield and JBS, which have reduced U.S. hog farms by over 70% since 1980. Proposition 12, he states, creates a premium market for family farmers investing in higher-welfare systems, with about 27% of producers already compliant. Maxwell concludes that Congress should not 'fix' Proposition 12 but instead address the broken market structures that threaten independent farmers’ livelihoods.

**Govt's Independent Animal Welfare Experts Disagreed With Pig Welfare Reforms | Scoop News**
The New Zealand government's Animal Welfare Amendment (Regulations of Management of Pigs) Bill, introduced by Minister Damien Hoggard, allows pig farmers to continue using farrowing crates until December 2035, with gradual restrictions—limiting crate use to three days before and four days after birth after that date. This contrasts sharply with the National Animal Welfare Advisory Committee (NAWAC)'s 2022 recommendation to fully ban farrowing crates, which it deemed necessary to meet the Animal Welfare Act’s minimum standards. NAWAC chairperson Matthew Stone stated that current practices fall below legal standards and that the proposed changes—such as a 13.3% increase in space for piglets and the provision of 'manipulable and deformable' materials—do not adequately address sows’ need for nest-building behavior. NAWAC had recommended space increases of 56% or 140%, which would allow pigs to lie laterally. Critics, including SPCA chief science advisor Arnja Dale and Green Party spokesperson Steve Abel, argue the government ignored expert advice and misled the public by claiming five years of broad consultation, when the main consultation in 2022 was on a different, more stringent proposal. Hoggard defended the bill, citing a balance between animal welfare and economic feasibility, noting that his proposed $678,000 in capital costs are significantly lower than NAWAC’s estimated $1.57 million. The Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) stated over 4,500 public submissions were received, but Dale and Abel argue the consultation was skewed toward industry interests, particularly NZ Pork, with whom Hoggard held at least eight meetings. MPI confirmed NAWAC will be involved in the upcoming Primary Production Committee process, but Stone declined to comment further, stating he would only speak if instructed by the Minister. The bill passed its first reading in Parliament, with Hoggard asserting the reforms would be among the world’s highest, noting only three countries have banned farrowing crates, all with taxpayer-funded subsidies.

**Spanish Supreme Court Blocks Europe’s Largest Proposed Pig Farm in Noviercas, Soria**
The Spanish Supreme Court has issued a final ruling dismissing the appeal by the company behind the proposed pig farming project in Noviercas, Soria, effectively blocking what would have been Europe's largest intensive livestock farm. The decision was celebrated by environmental organizations Amigas de la Tierra, Ecologistas en Acción, Greenpeace, and WWF, who argued the project threatened sustainable food systems, caused animal suffering, and exceeded planetary limits. The project was previously halted by Royal Decree 1053/2022, which set a maximum limit of 850 Large Livestock Units (UGM)—equivalent to about 725 dairy cows and rearing stock—for new or expanded farms across Spain. This measure eliminated the possibility of constructing the Noviercas macrofarm and similar projects. In 2023, Valle de Odieta S.C.L., Ganados Jiménez Cambra, and Can Trébol challenged the decree, prompting the environmental groups to intervene as defendants to defend its legality. The Supreme Court had previously dismissed appeals from the other two companies, but the final ruling on Valle de Odieta’s appeal has now been delivered. Jaime Doreste, the lawyer representing the environmental groups, stated, 'The justice has put a final end to what would have been Europe’s largest intensive farm, so we are celebrating. After years of waiting, this ruling arrives at the perfect moment to send a message to society and the sector: intensive farms make no sense in a planet on fire.'

MPI stated over 4,500 public submissions were received, and the final decision reflects a balance between welfare and economic realities. **Corporate Ag is losing  --  and the right is waking up**
With the Farm Bill deadline approaching, large agricultural lobbyists are attempting to use legislation to overturn California's Proposition 12, a seven-year-old law requiring improved animal welfare standards for farm animals sold in the state. However, an unexpected coalition is emerging: over 200 independent family farmers from 30 states, including companies like Niman Ranch, Heritage Foods, Butcher Box, and White Oak Pastures, have traveled to Washington, D.C., to oppose the 'Save Our Bacon Act' (SOB Act), a rebranded version of the failed EATS Act. The SOB Act, sponsored by Rep. Ashley Hinson (R-IA), would nullify Prop 12, Massachusetts’s Question 3, and hundreds of other state animal welfare laws, according to a Harvard Law analysis. These state laws, upheld by courts including the U.S. Supreme Court, require space for sows to stand, lie down, and turn around. Farmers have invested millions in infrastructure and created jobs to comply. Even JBS, the second-largest U.S. pork producer, is largely compliant. Fourteen House Republicans, led by Reps. Anna Paulina Luna and Nancy Mace, have warned the SOB Act undermines states' rights, harms family farmers, and increases foreign control over U.S. food. General Michael Flynn called it a 'national security threat.' Former EATS Act sponsor Senator Roger Marshall (R-KS) admitted on RFD-TV that 'we're getting the heck beat out of us' and declined to reintroduce the bill. Prop 12 has survived nine legal challenges, and the Department of Justice recently sued California on behalf of corporate interests, highlighting the entrenched opposition. Yet, support is growing: consumer demand for animal welfare is accelerating, and the law reflects voter choice, not government overreach. The irony is that Prop 12 aligns with conservative values like states' rights, consumer freedom, and local control. It also supports public health—better animal treatment reduces stress, disease, and antibiotic use. Republicans have previously advanced animal welfare, including Trump’s federal ban on animal cruelty and Kennedy’s efforts to end NIH animal testing. The corporate agriculture strategy of rebranding failed legislation is failing. The growing alliance of farmers, conservatives, and consumers now sees fair competition, not federal interference, as the future of American food. Farmers have invested, voters have spoken, and the tide is turning. As Butcher Box CEO Mike Salguero stated, undermining Prop 12 punishes those who complied and betrays consumer choice. The right is waking up: defending Prop 12 is about protecting free markets, states’ rights, and public health—not letting Washington decide what’s on our plates.

**Farmers are defending the law big pork wants to destroy**
Joe Maxwell, a fourth-generation Missouri hog farmer and president of Farm Action Fund, defends California's Proposition 12, which establishes minimum space standards for animals sold in California, arguing it is not a threat to independent family farmers but rather a market opportunity. He contrasts the interests of large corporate pork producers, represented by the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC), with those of small-scale farmers who benefit from higher welfare standards. Maxwell refutes claims that Proposition 12 caused a 41% rise in pork prices, noting that the significant increase occurred years before the law took effect during pandemic-related market corrections. He asserts that retail pork chop prices in California rose only 6.6% since enforcement began in January 2024, a normal market adjustment. Maxwell emphasizes that the law upholds state authority under federalism, affirmed by the Supreme Court, and warns that proposed federal bills like the Food Security and Farm Protection Act and the Save Our Bacon Act would strip states of this right, favoring corporate control. He argues that the real issue is corporate consolidation, weak antitrust enforcement, and vertical integration by multinational packers like Smithfield and JBS, which have reduced U.S. hog farms by over 70% since 1980. Proposition 12, he states, creates a premium market for family farmers investing in higher-welfare systems, with about 27% of producers already compliant. Maxwell concludes that Congress should not 'fix' Proposition 12 but instead address the broken market structures that threaten independent farmers’ livelihoods.

**Trump Asks Supreme Court To Rule on Nat Guard Deployment to Chicago**
The Trump administration has requested the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn a lower court ruling that blocked the federalization and deployment of National Guard troops to Chicago, as part of President Trump's crime crackdown. In a filing on October 18, 2025, the Justice Department argued that a district court judge in Illinois, April Perry, had improperly substituted her judgment for the President's on military matters under Section 12406 of federal law, which permits federalization when there is a breakdown of law and order. Judge Perry had ruled on October 9, 2025, that there was no evidence of such a breakdown, noting that federal agents who were threatened or assaulted had already been arrested. The Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals declined to block the deployment but affirmed the President’s authority to federalize troops. U.S. Solicitor General D. John Sauer asserted that the district court lacked both authority and competence to override the Commander in Chief’s control over the military chain of command. The administration has faced multiple legal challenges in deploying National Guard and federal agents to Illinois, Oregon, and California, with the Ninth Circuit recently allowing federalization in Oregon but not deployment due to ongoing violence. The administration denies allegations of violating the Posse Comitatus Act in California, where National Guard and Marine units were deployed.

**Color manufacturing group sues WV officials over ban on food dyes**
The International Association of Color Manufacturers (IACM) filed a lawsuit on October 6, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia against several state officials, including Department of Health Secretary Arvin Singh, Interim Bureau of Health Commissioner Justin Davis, Superintendent of Schools Michele Blatt, and members of the West Virginia Board of Education. The lawsuit challenges House Bill 2354, signed into law by Governor Patrick Morrisey in March 2025, which bans the use of six synthetic food color additives—FD&C Red No. 40, FD&C Yellow No. 5, FD&C Yellow No. 6, FD&C Blue No. 1, FD&C Blue No. 2, and other ingredients—in food and beverages sold in general commerce starting January 1, 2028, and in school meals beginning in 2028. The IACM argues that the law violates the U.S. and West Virginia constitutions by usurping the FDA’s authority over food safety, interfering with interstate commerce, and causing economic harm without a rational or scientific basis. The group asserts that these dyes have been evaluated and approved as safe by the FDA, the European Food Safety Agency, Health Canada, and the FAO/WHO Joint Expert Committee on Food Additives for decades. The complaint states that the law lacks any scientific evidence, legislative findings, or robust record to justify the ban and calls it a 'pseudoscientific fad' driven by arbitrary political action. The IACM also claims the law creates consumer confusion, increases food costs, and imposes significant technical and supply chain challenges in replacing synthetic dyes with natural alternatives, which are not a simple substitute. The group warns the ban may reduce the appeal of healthy food options and complicate schools’ ability to meet federal nutrition standards. IACM seeks a court order declaring HB 2354 unconstitutional and unenforceable, enjoining its implementation, and recovering court costs and attorney fees. The group is represented by attorneys from Frost Brown Todd and Stein Mitchell Beato and Missner. Governor Morrisey’s office defends the law, stating it aims to 'clean up our food and protect the health and well-being of West Virginia families,' citing bans in European countries due to health concerns, particularly in children. The IACM counters that companies have already adapted to similar bans abroad and that the five-year transition period is insufficient for a nonscientific mandate.

**Higher Education Litigation Summary: October 14, 2025**
The Thompson Coburn Higher Education Litigation Summary for October 14, 2025, provides a comprehensive overview of key legal developments in U.S. higher education. The U.S. Department of Education (ED) published the 2023 Gainful Employment Rule (GE Rule), which uses debt-to-earnings and earnings premium tests to assess program value; after two lawsuits from cosmetology schools challenged the rule as exceeding statutory authority and being arbitrary and capricious, the Northern District of Texas upheld the rule on October 2, 2025, ruling that 'gainful employment' reasonably means profitable employment and that ED’s use of IRS data and cost-benefit analysis was rational. The 2023 GE Rule remains in effect nationwide. The 'Bare Minimum Rule' (BMR), which restricted Title IV aid to programs meeting state licensure minimums, was enjoined nationwide by the Northern District of Texas in June 2024 due to its departure from 30 years of precedent; ED has since stayed the litigation and plans to reconsider the rule via negotiated rulemaking, with the case stayed until January 21, 2026. The 2022 Borrower Defense to Repayment (BDR) Rule faced a nationwide injunction by the Fifth Circuit in April 2024; the Supreme Court reviewed the issue but dismissed the case on August 8, 2025, after Congress passed the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBB), which restored pre-2020 regulations and invalidated the BDR provisions. The SAVE Plan, which offered 10-year loan forgiveness, remains enjoined due to lack of statutory authority, and the OBBB has replaced it, with interest resuming on August 1, 2025. A proposed rule for loan forgiveness under a different statute was withdrawn in December 2024, and litigation remains active over whether a live case or controversy exists. The 2024 Title IX Rule, which expanded protections to include gender identity and sexual orientation, was vacated nationwide by the Eastern District of Kentucky on January 9, 2025, on grounds of exceeding statutory authority and violating the First Amendment; ED has not appealed, and pending appeals in other circuits are being reviewed in light of the ruling. Upcoming Supreme Court cases—Little v. Hecox and B.P.J. v. West Virginia—will determine whether state bans on transgender athletes in girls’ and women’s sports violate the Equal Protection Clause or Title IX. The constitutionality of the False Claims Act’s qui tam provision remains under judicial scrutiny.

**NLRB sues California over new law empowering state agency to enforce federal labor rights**
The National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) has sued California to block Assembly Bill 288 (AB 288), a law signed by Governor Gavin Newsom in September 2025 that empowers the state's Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to oversee private-sector labor disputes and union elections when the federal NLRB is unable or unwilling to act. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California on October 18, 2025, argues that the law usurps the NLRB’s exclusive federal authority by regulating areas reserved for federal oversight. This action mirrors the NLRB’s prior legal challenge to a similar New York law. The NLRB contends that such state laws create conflicting parallel regulatory systems that undermine federal labor law. The crisis stems from the January 2025 firing of Democratic NLRB member Gwynne Wilcox by President Trump, which left the board without a quorum, effectively paralyzing its ability to rule on cases. Although Wilcox has challenged her firing in court, the Supreme Court has upheld the dismissal for now. California lawmakers and labor advocates, including Lorena Gonzalez, president of the California Federation of Labor Unions, argue AB 288 is essential to fill a critical gap, calling it 'the most significant labor law reform in nearly a century.' The law will take effect on January 1, 2026, allowing private-sector workers to petition the state board when federal cases have been pending for over six months, or when the NLRB lacks a quorum. The NLRB’s acting general counsel, William Cowen, a Trump appointee, claims the agency’s operations remain largely functional, with regional offices continuing to process union elections and unfair labor practice charges, asserting that only a small fraction of cases require full board decisions.

**Beltway Buzz, October 17, 2025**
As of October 17, 2025, the U.S. federal government has been partially shut down for 17 days with no clear political path to reopening. The U.S. Senate has attempted, and failed, to pass a continuing resolution ten times. Senators John Fetterman (D-PA), Catherine Cortez Masto (D-NV), and Angus King (I-ME) continue to support the resolution, while Senator Rand Paul (R-KY) opposes it. Republicans are seeking five additional Democratic votes to pass the measure. Meanwhile, E-Verify has resumed operations during the shutdown, requiring employers to create new cases for employees hired while the system was down by October 14, 2025. On immigration, the U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear a challenge to the 2015 H-4 EAD rule, preserving a 2024 D.C. Circuit decision that affirmed the rule’s validity under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Biden administration did not pursue rescinding the rule, and it remains on the Unified Agenda without any current plans for revision, though a future Trump administration could propose changes. In California, Governor Gavin Newsom signed Assembly Bill No. 288, expanding the Public Employee Relations Board (PERB) to handle private-sector union elections, unfair labor practice charges, and remedies—actions previously reserved for the NLRB. The NLRB sued California, arguing the law preempts federal labor law under the National Labor Relations Act. Senator Bill Cassidy (R-LA), chairman of the Senate HELP Committee, also criticized the law in a letter to Newsom, demanding details on implementation and warning that state actions undermine federal worker protections. On a separate note, October 17, 2025, marked the 45th anniversary of the Staggers Rail Act, which deregulated freight railroads, allowing them to negotiate rates and restructure services, leading to lower shipping costs, infrastructure investment, and the survival of the U.S. freight rail industry.

**Massachusetts is taking its victory in Triumph Foods v. Campbell to Washington D.C.**
Massachusetts is advancing its legal defense of Question 3 (Q3), a 2016 ballot initiative that bans the sale of pork, eggs, and veal from animals confined in cages too small to turn around or extend their limbs, following a favorable ruling in the Triump Foods v. Campbell case by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. The 47-page decision upheld the Massachusetts Act, stating it does not violate the Full Faith and Credit Clause because it does not prohibit out-of-state farming practices—only the sale of products from such practices within Massachusetts—and thus does not constitute a 'policy of hostility' toward states with Right to Farm laws. The court also ruled that Q3 does not preempt the Federal Meat Inspection Act (FMIA). This follows the U.S. Supreme Court’s June 30, 2024, denial of the Iowa Pork Producers Association’s (IPPA) appeal of a prior Ninth Circuit ruling that upheld California’s Proposition 12. Prop 12, passed in 2018 and fully implemented in 2024, requires minimum space standards: 24 square feet per sow, 43 square feet per veal calf, and cage-free housing for laying hens. Supporters like Brent Hershey, president of Hershey Ag, report improved farm resilience and productivity under Prop 12. Russ Kremer, a Missouri hog farmer, and Mike Salguero, CEO of ButcherBox, emphasized that Prop 12 supports family farmers and aligns with growing consumer demand for animal welfare. The House Committee on Agriculture held a full hearing on July 23, 2025, on the economic impact of Prop 12. Hopes for overturning such state laws now rest on proposed federal legislation, including the 'Save Our Bacon Act' and the 'Food Security and Farm Protection Act' (formerly the EATS Act).

On October 8, 2025, over 200 hog farmers from 30 states will gather at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C., alongside meat companies and retailers, to oppose the Save Our Bacon Act and Food Security and Farm Protection Act (formerly the EATS Act), which they argue threatens family farms and responsible farming. The coalition is defending California’s Proposition 12 and Massachusetts’s Question 3—laws that ban gestation crates and mandate humane animal housing. David Valadao (CA), Anna Paulina Luna (FL), Andrew Garbarino (NY) and others, including Gus Bilirakis, Vern Buchanan, Byron Donalds, Carlos Gimenez, Young Kim, Michael Lawler, Nancy Mace and Brian Fitzpatrick. **Supreme Court upholds Prop 12 in California**
The U.S. Supreme Court upheld California’s Proposition 12, a law regulating animal confinement, in a 5-4 decision against the National Pork Producers Council (NPPC) and the American Farm Bureau Federation (AFBF), who had challenged the law on grounds that it violated the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution. The ruling affirmed lower court decisions, including a 2021 Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals decision that had previously rejected the challenge. Under Prop 12, veal calves must have at least 43 sq. ft. of usable floor space per animal, sows must have a minimum of 24 sq. ft., and laying hens must be cage-free. The NPPC expressed disappointment, stating the ruling would increase consumer prices, harm small farms, and lead to industry consolidation, and vowed to continue opposing the law. The North American Meat Institute echoed this sentiment, calling Prop 12 a costly burden with no benefit to animals or consumers, and said it would study the ruling to determine next steps. In contrast, the Humane Society of the United States (HSUS) welcomed the decision, with President Kitty Block stating that the ruling affirms states’ authority to prevent animal cruelty and protect public health. The dissenting justices were Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Samuel Alito, Brett Kavanaugh, and Ketanji Brown Jackson.

summary:
Experts across the domains of agricultural regulation, public policy, constitutional and administrative law, political science, and animal science overwhelmingly agree that California’s 2018 Proposition 12 is highly likely to remain in effect on January 1, 2026. All forecasts converge around a high probability outcome (ranging from 85% to 95%), with none placing the risk of suspension or overturning above 15%.

Key factors supporting this judgment include:
- Strong judicial precedent: The Supreme Court upheld Prop 12 in 2023, and has since declined to revisit the issue despite ongoing federal lawsuits, notably from Triumph Foods. Lower courts continue to follow this precedent.
- Legislative inertia and opposition: Although the House Farm Bill contains preemption language that could nullify portions of Prop 12, significant bipartisan resistance (including from at least 14 House Republicans), active lobbying by family farmers, and ongoing Congressional gridlock (exacerbated by a government shutdown) make rapid passage or enactment highly unlikely before the resolution date.
- Industry adaptation: A substantial and growing share of pork and veal producers, including major companies, have adapted their operations and supply chains to comply with Prop 12, generating sunk costs and new coalitions invested in the status quo. This reduces both economic urgency and political support for repeal.
- Public and political support: Prop 12 enjoys continued broad public support in California and growing acknowledgment among national policymakers, partly due to successful messaging around states’ rights and local farm interests.
- Low base rate for late intervention: Historically, voter-approved California ballot initiatives—especially those recently affirmed by the Supreme Court—are very rarely suspended or repealed in under a decade absent a federal override or court order.

All experts agree that the remaining risk centers almost entirely on the remote chance that Congress swiftly passes a Farm Bill or standalone legislation with explicit preemption language, or that a federal court issues an injunction based on new legal arguments. Both are judged as very unlikely during the final 2.5 months of 2025, due to time constraints, institutional inertia, and political division.

In sum, the consensus is that Proposition 12’s provisions on confinement standards for veal calves, breeding pigs, and egg-laying hens, as well as sales restrictions, will continue to be enforced in California on January 1, 2026, absent an unexpectedly rapid federal intervention.
